D only
 About Users, Groups, and Policies
A user's permissions to access Oracle Cloud Infrastructure services comes from the groups to which they belong. The permissions for a group are defined by policies . Policies define what actions members of a group can perform, and in which compartments. Users can then access services and perform operations based on the policies set for the groups they are members of.
IAM group policy....D is pretty logical
D is correct because it will grant the employee the access to create resources .

choices.B: Delete the account and create another one.
choices.A: Send the employee API Signing Keys to log in.
choices.C: Make sure that the employee is logging in to the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure account from your corporate network only.
choices.D: Add the employee to a group with policies to grant access to relevant resources.

questions.question_text:
A new employee has just started working for your company. You create an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure user account for this employee, following which they are able to log in, but still cannot create any resources.
What should you do to resolve this?
Which two are true for achieving High Availability on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
C&E. 
Volumes are only accessible to instances in the same availability domain . You cannot move a volume between availability domains or regions, they are only accessible within the region or availability domain they were created in.
Block volumes are AD specific. So, C & E is the correct answer

CE are correct.

If you create cris-cross connection like mentioned in B, and if on AD comes down your system is still not available because only one part of the system is present

comments.content:
B is wrong. "Volumes are only accessible to instances in the same availability domain".
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Concepts/overview.htm

choices.D: Store your database files on Object Storage so that they are available in all Availability Domains in all regions.
choices.C: Configure your database to have Data Guard in another Availability Domain in Sync mode within a region.
choices.B: Attach your block volume form Availability Domain 1 to a compute instance in Availability Domain 2 (and vice versa) so that they are highly available.
choices.A: Store your database across multiple regions so that half of the data resides in one region and the other half resides in another region.
choices.E: Distribute your application servers across all Availability Domains within a region.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about subnets within a VCN? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: AD are correct. C is just wrong, the routing device wouldn't know where to send if C was true. I don't think I understand what B is trying to say. AD already pop out.
AD very correct, NB CIDR rule: instances should not overlap their ip address

choices.C: Subnets can have their IP addresses overlap with other subnets in another network for a given VCN.
choices.B: Private and Public subnets cannot reside in the same Availability Domain for a given VCN.
choices.A: You can have multiple subnets in an Availability Domain for a given VCN.
choices.D: Instances obtain their private IP and the associated security list from their subnets.

questions.question_text: Which resource is required when connecting to your on-premises network from your Virtual Cloud Network (VCN) via IPSec VPN or FastConnect?

discussion.content: B is correct. Allows for dynamic routing using BGP.

questions.question_text: Which two resources are availability domain constructs? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Availability Domain-Specific Resources
DB Systems
ephemeral public IPs
instances: They can be attached only to volumes in the same availability domain.
subnets: When you create a subnet, you choose whether it is regional or specific to an availability domain. Oracle recommends using regional subnets.
volumes: They can be attached only to an instance in the same availability domain.
